moves.1. e4: Here's a League game where, again, I've followed Ion's advice and avoided swapping off at the end, when it's a race to mate and I win by one move :-)
moves.2. Bc4: and White adopts the fashionable (on Gameknot at any rate) 2. Bc4
moves.4. exd5 exd5 5. Bb5+: sidestepping with the equally popular Bb5
moves.5... Nd7 6. O-O: White appears to be well ahead in development, as is often the case early in the Sicilian.
moves.6... Ngf6 7. Re1+ Be7 8. Nc3 O-O: but Black has equalised now since White's d-pawn is still at home.
moves.9. Bxd7 Bxd7 10. d3 Re8 11. Bg5 h6 12. B: Now Black has the advantage of the Bishop Pair on a  relatively open board.  Can he use it?
moves.13. Nxd5: ! Snapping up the loose pawn and threatening to disrupt Black's kingside
moves.13... Bc6 14. Nxf6+: ? Better was 14. Rxe8  when 14... Qxe8 allows 15. Nxf6 , when Black has to retake with the g-pawn.  Otherwise 14. ...Bxe8 puts Black's bishop on a bad square and the good bishop falls with 15. Nxf6
moves.14... Qxf6 15. c3 Rad8 16. d4: ? Better was 16. Rxe8  (again), when Black can't divert White's attention from the d-file.  White also has to watch out for his N on f3.  He shouldn't allow Black to give him doubled f-pawns.
moves.16... Rxe1+ 17. Qxe1 Bxf3 18. gxf3 cxd4: Now material is even but White has a structural weakness.  Is this enough to give Black victory?
moves.20. Qc3: Defends the f-pawn, pins the R against the Q (if Black allowed White to capture on f6, he would return the compliment of the doubled f-pawns, unless, of course he used his R to defend the Q) and threatens Qc8 , winning the b-pawn: looks good.
moves.20... Qg6+: side-stepping with check on the open file
moves.22... Qf5: doubling the attack on the weak f-pawn
moves.23. Ke1 Qxf3: converting the structural advantage into a material one.  Would this be enough to justify allowing swapping off yet?
moves.24. Qe2: Here, I tried to make 24...Qh1  work but couldn't.  I wanted to avoid a situation where I was chasing his pawns on his 2nd rank while he was doing the same to mine on mine.  His K was slightly better placed to defend than mine.
moves.24... Qf5: So I retreated again: he who runs away lives to fight another day!
moves.25. Rc1 Rd7: defending my second rank to give my Q time to harrass his.
moves.26. Qc2 Qe6+ 27. Qe2 Qd5 28. Rc8+ Kh7 29: threatening Q/R-h8   but what has White overlooked?
